doomsday. Go, get thee in and fetch me a stoup of
liquor.

lg.l: In youth, when I did love, did love,
Methought it was very sweet,
To contract â O â the time for â a â my behoove,
O, methought, there â a â was nothing â a â meet.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Has this fellow no feeling of his business, 'a sings
in grave-making?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: Custom hath made it in him a property of easiness.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: 'Tis e'en so: the hand of little employment hath the
daintier sense.

lg.l: But age, with his stealing steps,
Hath clawed me in his clutch,
And hath shipped me into the land,
As if I had never been such.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: That skull had a tongue in it, and could sing
once: how the knave jowls it to the ground, as
if 'twere Cain's jaw-bone, that did the first
murder! This might be the pate of a politician,
which this ass now o'erreaches; one that would
circumvent God, might it not?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: It might, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Or of a courtier; which could say âGood morrow,
sweet lord! How dost thou, sweet lord?â This
might be my lord such-a-one, that praised my lord
such-a-one's horse, when 'a meant to beg it; might it
not?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Why, e'en so: and now my Lady Worm's; chapless,
and knocked about the mazzard with a sexton's
spade: here's fine revolution, an we had the
trick to see't. Did these bones cost no more the
breeding, but to play at loggats with 'em? mine ache
to think on't.

lg.l: A pick-axe, and a spade, a spade,
For and a shrouding sheet:
O, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: There's another: why may not that be the skull
of a lawyer? Where be his quiddities now, his
quillities, his cases, his tenures, and his
tricks? why does he suffer this mad knave now to
knock him about the sconce with a dirty shovel,
and will not tell him of his action of battery?
Hum! This fellow might be in's time a great
buyer of land, with his statutes, his recognizances,
his fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries:
is this the fine of his fines, and the recovery
of his recoveries, to have his fine pate full of
fine dirt? will his vouchers vouch him no more
of his purchases, and double ones too, than the
length and breadth of a pair of indentures? The
very conveyances of his lands will scarcely lie
in this box; and must the inheritor himself have no
more, ha?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: Not a jot more, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Is not parchment made of sheep-skins?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: Ay, my lord, and of calf-skins too.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: They are sheep and calves which seek out assurance
in that. I will speak to this fellow. Whose grave's
this, sirrah?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Mine, sir.

lg.l: O, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I think it be thine, indeed; for thou liest in't.

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: You lie out on't, sir, and therefore 'tis not
yours: for my part, I do not lie in't, yet it is mine.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Thou dost lie in't, to be in't and say it is
thine: 'tis for the dead, not for the quick; therefore
thou liest.

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: 'Tis a quick lie, sir; 'twill away again, from me to
you.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: What man dost thou dig it for?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: For no man, sir.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: What woman, then?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: For none, neither.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Who is to be buried in't?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: One that was a woman, sir; but, rest her soul, she's
dead.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: How absolute the knave is! we must speak by the
card, or equivocation will undo us. By the Lord,
Horatio, this three years I have took note of
it; the age is grown so picked that the toe of
the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier, he
galls his kibe. How long hast thou been grave-maker?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Of all the days i' the year, I came to't that day that
our last king Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: How long is that since?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Cannot you tell that? every fool can tell that:
it was that very day that young Hamlet was born; he
that is mad, and sent into England.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Why, because 'a was mad: 'a shall recover his
wits there; or, if 'a do not, 'tis no great matter
there.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Why?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: 'Twill not be seen in him there; there the men are as
mad as he.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: How came he mad?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Very strangely, they say.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: How strangely?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Faith, e'en with losing his wits.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Upon what ground?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Why, here in Denmark: I have been sexton here, man and
boy, thirty years.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: How long will a man lie i' the earth ere he rot?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Faith, if 'a be not rotten before 'a die as we
have many pocky corses that will scarce hold the
laying in 'a will last you some eight year or nine
year: a tanner will last you nine year.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Why he more than another?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: Why, sir, his hide is so tanned with his trade,
that 'a will keep out water a great while; and
your water is a sore decayer of your whoreson
dead body. Here's a skull now; hath lien you i' the
earth three and twenty years.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: A whoreson mad fellow's it was: whose do you think it
was?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Nay, I know not.

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: A pestilence on him for a mad rogue! 'a poured
a flagon of Rhenish on my head once. This same
skull, sir, was, sir, Yorick's skull, the king's
jester.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: This?

sp.speaker: First Clown
sp.ab: E'en that.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio: a fellow
of infinite jest, of most excellent fancy: he
hath bore me on his back a thousand times; and
now, how abhorred in my imagination it is! my
gorge rises at it. Here hung those lips that I
have kissed I know not how oft. Where be your
gibes now? your gambols? your songs? your flashes
of merriment, that were wont to set the table on
a roar? Not one now, to mock your own grinning?
quite chap-fallen? Now get you to my lady's
chamber, and tell her, let her paint an inch
thick, to this favour she must come; make her laugh at
that. Prithee, Horatio, tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: What's that, my lord?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Dost thou think Alexander looked a' this fashion i'
the earth?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: E'en so.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: And smelt so? pah!

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: E'en so, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: To what base uses we may return, Horatio! Why
may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander,
till 'a find it stopping a bung-hole?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: 'Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: No, faith, not a jot; but to follow him thither
with modesty enough, and likelihood to lead it:
Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander
returneth to dust; the dust is earth; of earth
we make loam; and why of that loam, whereto he was
converted, might they not stop a beer-barrel?

lg.l: Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay,
Might stop a hole to keep the wind away:
O, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,
Should patch a wall to expel the winter's flaw!

sp.l: But soft! but soft awhile: here comes the king, Enter Priests, c. in procession; the Corpse of OPHELIA, LAERTES and Mourners following; KING, QUEEN, their trains, c.
The queen, the courtiers: who is this they follow?
And with such maimed rites? This doth betoken
The corse they follow did with desperate hand
Fordo it own life: 'twas of some estate.
Couch we awhile and mark. Retiring with Horatio.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: What ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: That is Laertes, a very noble youth, mark.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: What ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Her obsequies have been as far enlarged
As we have warranty: her death was doubtful;
And, but that great command o'ersways the order,
She should in ground unsanctified been lodged
Till the last trumpet; for charitable prayers,
Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her:
Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants,
Her maiden strewments and the bringing home
Of bell and burial.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Must there no more be done?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: No more be done:
We should profane the service of the dead
To sing a requiem and such rest to her
As to peace-parted souls.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Lay her i' the earth:
And from her fair and unpolluted flesh
May violets spring! I tell thee, churlish priest,
A ministering angel shall my sister be,
When thou liest howling.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: What, the fair Ophelia!

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: Sweets to the sweet: farewell! Scattering flowers.
I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlet's wife;
I thought thy bride-bed to have decked, sweet maid,
And not have strewed thy grave.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: O, treble woe
Fall ten times treble on that cursed head,
Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense
Deprived thee of! Hold off the earth awhile,
Till I have caught her once more in mine arms: Leaps into the grave.
Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountain you have made,
To o'ertop old Pelion, or the skyish head
Of blue Olympus.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: What is he whose grief
Bears such an emphasis? whose phrase of sorrow
Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand
Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,
Hamlet the Dane. Leaps into the grave.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: The devil take thy soul! Grappling with him.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Thou pray'st not well.
I prithee, take thy fingers from my throat;
For, though I am not splenitive and rash,
Yet have I in me something dangerous,
Which let thy wisdom fear: hold off thy hand.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Pluck them asunder.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: Hamlet, Hamlet!

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Good my lord, be quiet. The Attendants part them, and they come out of the grave.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Why, I will fight with him upon this theme
Until my eyelids will no longer wag.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: O my son, what theme?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: I loved Ophelia: forty thousand brothers
Could not, with all their quantity of love,
Make up my sum. What wilt thou do for her?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O, he is mad, Laertes.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: For love of God, forbear him.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: 'Swounds, show me what thou'lt do:
Woo't weep? woo't fight? woo't fast? woo't tear thyself?
Woo't drink up eisel? eat a crocodile?
I'll do't. Dost thou come here to whine?
To outface me with leaping in her grave?
Be buried quick with her, and so will I:
And, if thou prate of mountains, let them throw
Millions of acres on us, till our ground,
Singeing his pate against the burning zone,
Make Ossa like a wart! Nay, an thou'lt mouth,
I'll rant as well as thou.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: This is mere madness:
And thus awhile the fit will work on him;
Anon, as patient as the female dove,
When that her golden couplets are disclosed,
His silence will sit drooping.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Hear you, sir;
What is the reason that you use me thus?
I loved you ever: but it is no matter;
Let Hercules himself do what he may,
The cat will mew and dog will have his day. Exit.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I pray thee, good Horatio, wait upon him. Exit Horatio. To Laertes
Strengthen your patience in our last night's speech;
We'll put the matter to the present push.
Good Gertrude, set some watch over your son.
This grave shall have a living monument:
An hour of quiet shortly shall we see;
Till then, in patience our proceeding be. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: So much for this, sir: now shall you see the other;
You do remember all the circumstance?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Remember it, my lord!

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting,
That would not let me sleep: methought I lay
Worse than the mutines in the bilboes. Rashly,
And praised be rashness for it, let us know,
Our indiscretion sometime serves us well,
When our deep plots do pall: and that should learn us
There's a divinity that shapes our ends,
Rough-hew them how we will,

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: That is most certain.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Up from my cabin,
My sea-gown scarfed about me, in the dark
Groped I to find out them; had my desire,
Fingered their packet, and in fine withdrew
To mine own room again; making so bold,
My fears forgetting manners, to unseal
Their grand commission; where I found, Horatio,
Ah, royal knavery! â an exact command,
Larded with many several sorts of reasons
Importing Denmark's health and England's too,
With ho! such bugs and goblins in my life,
That, on the supervise, no leisure bated,
No, not to stay the grinding of the axe,
My head should be struck off.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Here's the commission: read it at more leisure.
But wilt thou hear now how I did proceed?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Being thus be-netted round with villainies â
Or I could make a prologue to my brains,
They had begun the play â I sat me down,
Devised a new commission, wrote it fair:
I once did hold it, as our statists do,
A baseness to write fair and laboured much
How to forget that learning, but, sir, now
It did me yeoman's service: wilt thou know
The effect of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Ay, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: An earnest conjuration from the king,
As England was his faithful tributary,
As love between them like the palm might flourish,
As peace should still her wheaten garland wear
And stand a comma 'tween their amities,
And many such-like âAs'es of great charge,
That, on the view and knowing of these contents.
Without debatement further, more or less,
He should those bearers put to sudden death,
Not shriving time allowed.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: How was this sealed?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Why, even in that was heaven ordinant.
I had my father's signet in my purse,
Which was the model of that Danish seal;
Folded the writ up in the form of the other,
Subscribed it, gave't the impression, placed it safely,
The changeling never known. Now, the next day
Was our sea-fight; and what to this was sequent
Thou know'st already.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to't.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Why, man, they did make love to this employment;
They are not near my conscience; their defeat
Does by their own insinuation grow:
'Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Between the pass and fell incensed points
Of mighty opposites.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Why, what a king is this!

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Does it not, think thee, stand me now upon â
He that hath killed my king and whored my mother,
Popped in between the election and my hopes,
Thrown out his angle for my proper life,
And with such cozenage â is't not perfect conscience,
To quit him with this arm? and is't not to be damned,
To let this canker of our nature come
In further evil?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: It must be shortly known to him from England
What is the issue of the business there.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: It will be short: the interim's mine;
And a man's life's no more than to say âOne.â
But I am very sorry, good Horatio,
That to Laertes I forgot myself;
For, by the image of my cause, I see
The portraiture of his: I'll court his favours:
But, sure, the bravery of his grief did put me
Into a towering passion.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Peace! who comes here? Enter OSRIC.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I humbly thank you, sir. Dost know this water-fly?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: No. my good lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Thy state is the more gracious; for 'tis a vice
to know him. He hath much land, and fertile: let
a beast be lord of beasts, and his crib shall
stand at the king's mess: 'tis a chough; but, as I
say, spacious in the possession of dirt.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Sweet lord, if your lordship were at leisure, I should
impart a thing to you from his majesty.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I will receive it, sir, with all diligence of
spirit. Put your bonnet to his right use; 'tis for the
head.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: I thank your lordship, it is very hot.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: No, believe me, 'tis very cold; the wind is northerly.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for my
complexion.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Exceedingly, my lord; it is very sultry, as
'twere, I cannot tell how. My lord, his majesty
bade me signify to you that 'a has laid a great wager
on your head: sir, this is the matter,

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I beseech you, remember
sp.stage: Hamlet moves him to put on his hat.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Nay, good my lord; for my ease, in good faith.
Sir, here is newly come to court Laertes; believe
me, an absolute gentleman, full of most excellent
differences, of very soft society and great
showing: indeed, to speak feelingly of him, he
is the card or calendar of gentry, for you shall
find in him the continent of what part a gentleman
would see.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in you;
though, I know, to divide him inventorially would
dozy the arithmetic of memory, and yet but yaw
neither, in respect of his quick sail. But, in
the verity of extolment, I take him to be a soul
of great article; and his infusion of such dearth
and rareness, as, to make true diction of him,
his semblable is his mirror; and who else would trace
him, his umbrage, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: The concernancy, sir? why do we wrap the gentleman in
our more rawer breath?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Sir?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: Is't not possible to understand in another tongue? You
will to't, sir, really.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: What imports the nomination of this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Of Laertes?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: His purse is empty already; all's golden words are
spent.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Of him, sir.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: I know you are not ignorant

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I would you did, sir; yet, in faith, if you did, it
would not much approve me. Well. sir?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I dare not confess that, lest I should compare
with him in excellence; but, to know a man well, were
to know himself.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: I mean, sir, for his weapon; but in the imputation
laid on him by them, in his meed he's unfellowed.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: What's his weapon?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Rapier and dagger.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: That's two of his weapons: but, well.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: The king, sir, hath wagered with him six Barbary
horses: against the which he has impawned, as I
take it, six French rapiers and poniards, with
their assigns, as girdle, hangers, and so: three
of the carriages, in faith, are very dear to
fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate
carriages, and of very liberal conceit.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: What call you the carriages?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: I knew you must be edified by the margent ere you had
done.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: The carriages, sir, are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: The phrase would be more germane to the matter,
if we could carry a cannon by our sides: I would
it might be hangers till then. But, on: six
Barbary horses against six French swords, their
assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages;
that's the French bet against the Danish. Why is this
all âimpawned,â as you call it?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: The king, sir, hath laid, that in a dozen passes
between yourself and him, he shall not exceed
you three hits: he hath laid on twelve for nine;
and it would come to immediate trial, if your lordship
would vouchsafe the answer.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: How if I answer ânoâ?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: I mean, my lord, the opposition of your person in
trial.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Sir, I will walk here in the hall: if it please
his majesty, it is the breathing time of day with
me; let the foils be brought, the gentleman
willing, and the king hold his purpose, I will
win for him an I can; if not, I will gain nothing but
my shame and the odd hits.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: Shall I deliver you so?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: To this effect, sir; after what flourish your nature
will.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.ab: I commend my duty to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Yours.
'A does well to commend it himself; there are no
tongues else for's turn.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: This lapwing runs away with the shell on his head.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: 'A did comply, sir, with his dug, before 'a sucked
it. Thus has he and many more of the same breed
that I know the drossy age dotes on only got the
tune of the time and out of an habit of encounter;
a kind of yesty collection, which carries them
through and through the most fanned and winnowed
opinions; and do but blow them to their trial, the
bubbles are out.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.ab: My lord, his majesty commended him to you by
young Osric, who brings back to him, that you
attend him in the hall: he sends to know if your
pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will
take longer time.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I am constant to my purposes; they follow the
king's pleasure: if his fitness speaks, mine is ready;
now or whensoever, provided I be so able as now.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.ab: The king and queen and all are coming down.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: In happy time.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.ab: The queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment
to Laertes before you fall to play.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: She well instructs me.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: You will lose, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: I do not think so; since he went into France, I
have been in continual practice: I shall win at
the odds. Thou wouldst not think how ill all's here
about my heart: but it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: Nay, good my lord,

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: It is but foolery; but it is such a kind of
gain-giving, as would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.ab: If your mind dislike any thing, obey it: I will
forestall their repair hither, and say you are not
fit.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.ab: Not a whit, we defy augury: there is special
providence in the fall of a sparrow. If it be
now, 'tis not to come; if it be not to come, it
will be now; if it be not now, yet it will come:
the readiness is all: since no man of aught he leaves
knows what is't to leave betimes? Let be.
sp.stage: Enter KING, QUEEN, LAERTES, Lords, OSRIC, and Attendants with foils, c.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come, Hamlet, come, and take this hand from me. The King puts Laertes' hand into Hamlet's.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Give me your pardon, sir: I have done you wrong;
But pardon't, as you are a gentleman.
This presence knows,
And you must needs have heard, how I am punished
With a sore distraction. What I have done,
That might your nature, honour and exception
Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madness.
Was't Hamlet wronged Laertes? Never Hamlet:
If Hamlet from himself be ta'en away,
And when he's not himself does wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it.
Who does it, then? His madness: if't be so,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged;
His madness is poor Hamlet's enemy.
Sir, in this audience,
Let my disclaiming from a purposed evil
Free me so far in your most generous thoughts,
That I have shot my arrow o'er the house,
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: I am satisfied in nature,
Whose motive, in this case, should stir me most
To my revenge: but in my terms of honour
I stand aloof; and will no reconcilement,
Till by some elder masters, of known honour,
I have a voice and precedent of peace,
To keep my name ungored. But till that time,
I do receive your offered love like love,
And will not wrong it.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: I embrace it freely;
And will this brothers' wager frankly play.
Give us the foils. Come on.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Come, one for me.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: I'll be your foil, Laertes: in mine ignorance
Your skill shall, like a star i' the darkest night,
Stick fiery off indeed.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: You mock me, sir.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: No, by this hand.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Give them the foils, young Osric. Cousin Hamlet,
You know the wager?

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Very well, my lord;
Your grace has laid the odds a' the weaker side.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I do not fear it; I have seen you both:
But since he is bettered, we have therefore odds.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: This is too heavy, let me see another.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: This likes me well. These foils have all a length? They prepare to play.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.
If Hamlet give the first or second hit,
Or quit in answer of the third exchange,
Let all the battlements their ordnance fire;
The king shall drink to Hamlet's better breath;
And in the cup an union shall he throw,
Richer than that which four successive kings
In Denmark's crown have worn. Give me the cups;
And let the kettle to the trumpet speak,
The trumpet to the cannoneer without,
The cannons to the heavens, the heaven to earth,
âNow the king drinks to Hamlet.â Come, begin:
And you, the judges, bear a wary eye.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Come on, sir.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Come, my lord. They play.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: One.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Judgement.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: A hit, a very palpable hit.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Well; again.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Stay; give me drink. Hamlet, this pearl is thine;
Here's to thy health. Trumpets sound, and cannon shot off within. Give him the cup.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: I'll play this bout first; set it by awhile.
Come. They play.
Another hit; what say you?

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: A touch, a touch, I do confess't.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Our son shall win.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: He's fat, and scant of breath.
Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub thy brows:
The queen carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Good madam!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Gertrude, do not drink.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: I will, my lord; I pray you, pardon me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It is the poisoned cup: it is too late.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: I dare not drink yet, madam; by and by.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: Come, let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: My lord, I'll hit him now.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I do not think't.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: And yet it is almost against my conscience.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Come, for the third, Laertes: you do but dally;
I pray you, pass with your best violence;
I am sure you make a wanton of me.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Say you so? come on. They play.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Nothing, neither way.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Have at you now! Laertes wounds Hamlet; then, in scuffling, they change rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Part them: they are incensed.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Nay, come, again. The Queen falls.

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Look to the queen there, ho!

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: They bleed on both sides. How is it, my lord?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: How is't, Laertes?

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: Why, as a woodcock to mine own springe, Osric;
I am justly killed with mine own treachery.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: How does the queen?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She swoons to see them bleed.

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.l: No, no, the drink, the drink, O my dear Hamlet,
The drink, the drink! I am poisoned. Dies.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: O villainy! Ho! let the door be locked:
Treachery! Seek it out.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: It is here, Hamlet: Hamlet, thou art slain;
No medicine in the world can do thee good;
In thee there is not half an hour's life;
The treacherous instrument is in thy hand,
Unbated and envenomed: the foul practice
Hath turned itself on me; lo, here I lie,
Never to rise again: thy mother's poisoned:
I can no more: the king, the king's to blame.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: The point envenomed too!
Then, venom, to thy work. Stabs the King.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Treason! treason!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O, yet defend me, friends; I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damned Dane,
Drink off this potion. Is thy union here?
Follow my mother. King dies.

sp.speaker: Laertes
sp.l: He is justly served;
It is a poison tempered by himself.
Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet:
Mine and my father's death come not upon thee,
Nor thine on me! Dies.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: Heaven make thee free of it! I follow thee.
I am dead, Horatio. Wretched queen, adieu!
You that look pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes or audience to this act,
Had I but time â as this fell sergeant, death,
Is strict in his arrest â O, I could tell you
But let it be. Horatio, I am dead;
Thou livest; report me and my cause aright
To the unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Never believe it:
I am more an antique Roman than a Dane:
Here's yet some liquor left.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: As th' art a man,
Give me the cup: let go; by heaven, I'll have't.
O good Horatio, what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown, shall I leave behind me
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity awhile,
And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain,
To tell my story. March afar off, and shot within. What warlike noise is this?

sp.speaker: Osric
sp.l: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland,
To the ambassadors of England gives
This warlike volley.

sp.speaker: Hamlet
sp.l: O, I die, Horatio;
The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit:
I cannot live to hear the news from England;
But I do prophesy the election lights
On Fortinbras: he has my dying voice;
So tell him, with the occurrents, more and less,
Which have solicited. The rest is silence. Dies.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Now cracks a noble heart. Good night, sweet prince;
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!
Why does the drum come hither? March within. Enter FORTINBRAS, the English Ambassadors, and others.

sp.speaker: Fortinbras
sp.l: Where is this sight?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: What is it you would see?
If aught of woe or wonder, cease your search.

sp.speaker: Fortinbras
sp.l: This quarry cries on havoc. O proud death,
What feast is toward in thine eternal cell,
That thou so many princes at a shot
So bloodily hast struck?

sp.speaker: First Ambassador
sp.l: The sight is dismal;
And our affairs from England come too late:
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing,
To tell him his commandment is fulfilled,
That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead:
Where should we have our thanks?

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Not from his mouth,
Had it the ability of life to thank you:
He never gave commandment for their death.
But since, so jump upon this bloody question,
You from the Polack wars, and you from England,
Are here arrived, give order that these bodies
High on a stage be placed to the view;
And let me speak to the yet unknowing world
How these things came about: so shall you hear
Of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgements, casual slaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning and forced cause,
And, in this upshot, purposes mistook
Fall'n on the inventors' heads: all this can I
Truly deliver.

sp.speaker: Fortinbras
sp.l: Let us haste to hear it,
And call the noblest to the audience.
For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune:
I have some rights of memory in this kingdom,
Which now to claim my vantage doth invite me.

sp.speaker: Horatio
sp.l: Of that I shall have also cause to speak,
And from his mouth whose voice will draw on more:
But let this same be presently performed,
Even while men's minds are wild; lest more mischance,
On plots and errors, happen.

sp.speaker: Fortinbras
sp.l: Let four captains
Bear Hamlet, like a soldier, to the stage;
For he was likely, had he been put on,
To have proved most royal: and, for his passage,
The soldiers' music and the rite of war
Speak loudly for him.
Take up the bodies: such a sight as this
Becomes the field, but here shows much amiss.
Go, bid the soldiers shoot. A dead march. Exeunt, bearing off the dead bodies; after which a peal of ordnance is shot off.
